instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on 3V42/SMC
threads.message: Short on 3V42. Corrosion around <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> and nowhere else. I've removed the components in the 3V42 circuit surrounding <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> as they looked beat up. After that, the only thing that gets hot now with voltage injected is the SMC. No corrosion around SMC so it doesn't seem like cleanup under the chip is going to get me anywhere. Any thoughts on this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on 3V42/SMC
threads.message: Yeah corrosion around <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> caused 3V42 to go high. Probably everything on 3V42 is killed. SMC, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and you can figure out the rest.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on 3V42/SMC
threads.message: Ok, got it, thanks. was hoping it might possibly be something else.
